title: Math Ecology
text:
My classic academic training is in mathematical and statistical modeling of ecological systems.
My work primarily focuses on natural resource management. I use difference/differential equation modeling, agent-based modeling, matrix projection models, and more. Here are some highlights of my work:

Managing the sylvatic plague in black-tailed prairie dogs
De-extinction strategies for the passenger pigeon
Vaccination strategies for white-nose syndrome in little brown bats
Modeling sublethal stressors on bee colonies
Hunting strategies to suppress the winter tick epizootic in moose
Modeling pollen competition and interference in plants

My complete works can be found on my Google Scholar Profile
I enjoy working with interdisciplinary teams, and with colleagues across the world. If you‚Äôre interested in working together, please reach out to me!
I‚Äôve worked with several student researchers, from REUs, programs internal to UWL, federal scholar programs, etc. If you are interested in undergraduate research, please reach out to me!

title: CV
text: You can preview and download my CV at this link.

title: Coulee Data Center
text:
I founded the Coulee Data Center (CDC) in 2025. The CDC website is under construction! The mission of the CDC is to
‚Äú‚Ä¶deliver actionable, data-driven insights at no cost to non-profit organizations and public services in the Coulee Region of Southwestern Wisconsin and Southeastern Minnesota, empowering them to make informed decisions and amplify their impact.‚Äù
Each semester the CDC collaborates with a local partner on a data analysis project. Our first partner is Habitat for Humanity of the Greater La Crosse Region! More details about our work is available on our CDC website (under construction).
If you know of a local partner that would like to work with the CDC, or you would like to cover the work of the CDC, please reach out to me!
Each semester the CDC appoints up to three students as ‚ÄúData Diplomats‚Äù that work on these projects. If you‚Äôre interested in becoming a Data Diplomat, please reach out to me!

title: Our Mission
text:
The Coulee Data Center (CDC) was founded in 2025. Our mission is to:
‚Äú‚Ä¶deliver actionable, data-driven insights at no cost to non-profit organizations, community-focused groups, and public services in the Coulee region of Southwestern Wisconsin and Southeastern Minnesota, empowering them to make informed decisions and amplify their impact.‚Äù
Each semester the CDC collaborates with a local partner on a data analysis project. Find out more about our projects, becoming a partner, and meet our team!

title: Contact
text:
New Partner Opportunities
If you‚Äôre connected with either a non-profit organization, community-focused group, or public service, in the coulee region, and would like to amplify your impacts with data-driven insights, we would love to work with you!
We‚Äôre actively looking for new projects and happy to tailor our work to your needs. Please contact our director, David Elzinga, via email to get started: delzinga@uwlax.edu


Become a Lab Member
my work in mathematical ecology, have an opportunity you want to share, or have another inquiry, the best way to reach me is via email: delzinga@uwlax.edu.

title: Coulee Data Center
text:
The Coulee Data Center (CDC) is a community-focused data science organization. We partner with organizations in the Coulee region to amplify their impact by providing free data analysis.
On this website you can learn more about us, follow our work, become a partner, and even join our team.

title: DCE
text:
David C. Elzinga


Welcome to my professional website. I‚Äôm currently an Assistant Professor of Statistics at the University of Wisconsin-La Crosse.


This website is a great place to learn more about my lab, the Coulee Data Center, and my academic work in Mathematical Ecology.

title: Become a Partner
text: We provide free data insights to organizations that are non-profits, community-focused, or provide public services, within the coulee community of southeastern Minnesota and southwestern Wisconsin.

title: Join the Center
text:
Become a Center Member
Currently, the Coulee Data Center houses one director and three student data scientist positions. Most semesters, the Coulee Data Center is recruiting students to fill open positions from students that are graduating.
Students from all backgrounds are welcome to express interest in working for the CDC. Students should have some programming experience, an interest in data science, strong ethics, and believe in serving their community.
If you believe that‚Äôs you, reach out to our director, David Elzinga: delzinga@uwlax.edu. Funding opportunities are possible through various grant applications, with the greatest chances of funding being

title: Become a Partner
text: We provide free data insights to organizations that are non-profits, community-focused, or provide public services, within the coulee community of southeastern Minnesota and southwestern Wisconsin.

title: Become a Partner
text:
The Process

All partnerships begin by contacting our director, David Elzinga, via email: delzinga@uwlax.edu.
After contacting us, we‚Äôll plan a meeting to discuss your needs. If the partnership seems like a good fit, your project will be assigned to an academic semester.
Leading up to the semester, you‚Äôll work with the director to collect your data and define your goals. During the semester, our entire center (three students and one director) will work on your analysis, with occasional meetings with you to discuss progress and ask questions.
At the end of your semester you‚Äôll be delivered all of our results in whatever format is easiest for you. All of our analysis is publicly available, and may be published in scientific journals, but any sensitive data can be hidden at your request.

title: Become a Partner
text:
FAQs


Is it really free?

Yes.



What kinds of analysis are possible?

All kinds! We do everything from basic data organization to general statistics, data visualization, and machine learning. In generic terms, here is a non-exhaustive list of what we can help with:

Discovering trends in your data (seasonally, geographically, historically) and projecting them into the future.

Predicting outcomes that are yet to happen.

Identifying natural groupings among your observations.

Maximizing or minimizing some important quantity.

Check out our past and current projects for your reference.




Who is working on my project?

We house one faculty director and three student data scientists. All workers in the CDC are vetted for a commitment to rigorous ethics and community service. We are a group of data-loving people who have the educational and professional backgrounds to handle your project. Meet our team!



How is my data protected?

If you notify us that part (or all) of your data is sensitive, we‚Äôll work with you to limit access to only our team members. Otherwise, we believe in open-access science whenever possible, and all non-sensitive data is publicly available.



I don‚Äôt have any data, is that okay?

Maybe. We don‚Äôt do ‚Äúboots-on-the-ground‚Äù data collection services, but we are more than happy to help you with data collection guidelines. We are also experienced with scraping data off publicly available web sources if you‚Äôre aware of any relevant sites.



My data is messy, is that okay?

Yes, we love all data! Our team is experienced with cleaning, merging, and validating data.

title: Our Team
text:
David Elzinga


Director and Founder
Ph.D.¬†in Mathematics, 2023 M.S. in Statistics, 2023
I founded the Coulee Data Center in 2024, and have served as the director since its inception. I am passionate about serving my community, helping students, and data analysis - and the CDC combines all three!

title: Projects
text: Below is a list of our ongoing and previous projects. Interested in becoming a partner? Learn more about setting up a project!

title: Projects
text:
Habitat for Humanity (Spring 2025)

This work is wrapping up! We are excited to have worked with Habitat for Humanity of the Greater La Crosse Region (‚Äúhabitat‚Äù) on our inaugural project!
We are producing a historical review of the impact habitat has had on our communities. We‚Äôre synthesizing information on property taxes, home values, construction costs, and more!

Habitat will be able to use our report as a clear, objective, data-based measurement of their impact, hopefully aiding in their ability to secure competitive grants, reduce costs, and amplify their impact.
Pictured is our team presenting initial findings with Kahya Fox, the Executive Director of Habitat for Humanity. The final report can be found here.

title: Join the Center
text:
Due to limited resources, our team is relatively small. We house a director and three student data scientist positions.
Positions in the center do open regularly, so interested students are encouraged to reach out to our director, David Elzinga: delzinga@uwlax.edu.

What‚Äôs in it for you?

This is a great opportunity to get hands-on with a real-world data problem. You can discuss your experiences on these projects when you‚Äôre searching for jobs.
You get to give back to your community with your work making a real impact!
You‚Äôll gain valuable skills in programming, machine learning, statistics, data visualization, version management software (git), documentation, communication, working in a team, and more!

Funding wise, for the time being, these positions are generally unfunded (grant applications to change that are in the works). Funding may be possible with significant lead-time via internal scholarship applications.


Qualifications



Love data

Love programming

Love helping your community




Love working in a team

Love learning new skills

Love being challenged
